div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.

Shortest, calmest, most beautiful sea passage to Europe. Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Sofia, Belgrade, Budapest, Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Chios, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli, Constantinople.
SUDAN-EXPRESS MAIL SERVICE.

KHARTOUM IN 3 DAYS. Express Steamers leave Suez Docks 5 p.m. every Wedensday for Port Sudan (and Suakin) in connection with Sudan Government Railways Express Luxe service to Kharteum, arriving 8 p.m. Saturdays.
RED-SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.

Steamers leave from Suez 5 p.m. every Monday evening for JEDDA, calling one week at Tor, El Wedj, Yambo, Jedda; and the following week at Tor, Yambo, Jedda, Port Sudan, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, ADEN.
For freight or passage apply the Co.'s agencies Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, or for passage only to THOS, COOK & SON, HAMBURG-AMERIKA LINE, REISE-BUREAT or other Tourist Agenecies.

div.head: WELCOME TO EGYPT.
div.p: "THE GREEN HOWARDS."
A FAMOUS AND HISTORIC REGIMENT.

The Alexandra Princess of Wales's Own Yorkshire Regiment popularly known as the "Green Howards the 1st Battalion of which arrived here yesterday is a very old and distinctive guisbed regiment, and possesses a most interesting history The 1st Battalion came into existence in the closing weeks of 1688 when the Revolution had changed a dynasty. Pore most amagat the partisans of William of Orange was a certain Francis Lattrell, Somersetshire gentleman. To assist the Prince of Orange, be at once set about raising regiment for his service, and so enthusiastically did he work that in a very short space of time he had ten company regiment organised, equipped and armed. This regiment joined the banner of the Prince at Exeter, and Littrell became its first colonel

A nucleus had previously existed in the shape of some independent companies which lasted from the Seven Years' War Its first service seems to have been allocated in the Capacity of mannen A short spell of this service seems to have sufficed for in 1690 we find it in Ireland in William's Army, fighting gallantly at the Boyne and other actions At the death of Luttrell, which abortly followed the Irish campaign, Sir Thomas Erle was appointed to the command, and be brought the regiment to Flanders were it gained laurela at Steenkirk, and Landon and many other actions of the period. Erle rose from a sick beil to lead it at landen, and there was wounded bally whilst cheering on his men. It distinguished itself at the siege of Namur and can home to recruit in 1696 The regiment, which Was subsequently numbered the 19th Regiment of Foot bad a considerable spell of home service after its adventures in Flanders

The regiment served in the Cadiz expedition, and at the capture of the Spanish treasure ships at Vigo in 1702, after which it went to the West Indies, whence it returned, and remained at home until the spring pt 1709, when, at any rate, a part of it joined Marl borough's army in time to share in the famous victory at Malplaquet (11th September, 1709) At the storming of Douay it suffered loss. It was also at Bouchain It was predominantly engaged, likewise, at Pouta Vendin, and in other actions in Marlborough's campaigns After the peace of l'tracht the regiment was many years at home About this time, from

1738 to 1748, it was commanded by Chas Howard, second son of the third Earl of Carlisle, and one of George the Second's "captains. Having green facings, it became known is the "Green Howarda," to distinguish it from the Bafts, which were then known as "Howard's" after their colonel. George Howard, who commanded that regiment for a long period. The regimental connection with Yorkshire probably commenced at this time, although the regiment did not receive its county title until 1782

In 1774, the Regiment went to Flanders and there made a name for itself in many bard fought actions notably at Fontenoy, where the British were basely deserted by their Datch allies Roucoux, Val, etc.against six times their own numbers. It was whilst on this service that fifes were first introduced in the Britsb service and the Green Howards were the first to use that musical instrument At the outbreak of the Seven Years War it raised a second battalion, which was formed into the 66th Foot, and is now the 2nd Royal Berkshire Regiment late at Alexandria The 19th, the regiment now began to be called, took a prominent part in the famous siege and capture of Belle Isle, outbe coast of Brittany, in 1761; and subsequently was stationed at Gibraltar, whence it returned home in 1771 It went out to Charlestown, Carolina 11 1781, and was present in the wins at Monks Corney, the relief of Port Ninety Six, and the action at Eutaw Springs, and went through much harassing work up to the departure of the troopa and "loyalista" in December, 1782, when it removed to Barbadoen, and ultimately to Jamaica, where it remained until 1791 At the outbreak of the French war the regiment formed part of the expedition which cooperate with the French Royalists at Quiberoni, and afterwards landed at Ostend. It served the campaign of 1794 under the Duke of York, and shared in the disastrous winter retreat through Holland and West
balia to Brunn Its record also shows good work at Vieuport and Guildermalsen. lo 1796 It went out to India, and soon after we went

Ceylon. A detachment of five companies was sent to Madras in 1799, and took part in the capture of Seringspatam These companies were intended to accompany Baird's expedition np the Red Sea to Egypt, but instead went back to Ceylon. The regiment was employed at Kandy at various times, the massacre of one of its detachments, in 103, Wu of the most tragic character. The regiment was employed for some time in the Travancore district, and sent four companies to Isle Rodriguez, which took part in the capture of Mauritins (Isle of France, in 1810 It was also engaged in the Kandyan War of 1817 18 19, returning home in 1820, after twenty three years continuous service in Ceylon and the Past ludice It served in Demerara and the West Indies from 1826 to 1836, and in Malta, the louian Islands, the West Indies, and North America from 1840 to 1850.

At the outbreak of the Russian War, the 19th was despatched to the seat of war and earned new laurels at the Battle of Alma where it suffered considerably in the attack of the Russian guds, it lorses being two officers,

and 39 non commissioned officers and men -killed and five officers and 174 non commissioned officers and men wounded. At the "Soldier's Battle of Inkerman the handfal of the 19th - for wat and disease bad reduced it to a mere skeleton battalion-had their work cutout for them in stemming the tide of Romian soldiery which for bours threatened to annihilate the slender files opposed to it. Three companies rendered invaluable service in enabling General Codrington to hold the celebrated "Victoria Ridgo throughout the day, and other detachments covered themselves with glory, and lost heavily, nearly half their numbers killed or wounded. It served through out the siege of Sebastopol, taking part in the attack on the Quarties, and the s alt on the Redan. In the latter storm, the forlom bope leadersbip was tossed for between Colonel Unett, commanding the 19th, and Colonel Windham, Assistant Quartermanter General "My choice in modo", said Unett, m he turned over the shilling: "I shall be the first man ini de the Redan". But fortune ordained it other wise be fell badly wounded, early in the af fair Although the attack on the Redan w virtaally failare, throughi no fault of the sol diers, the Rumians were impressed by the valour of the red cats that they ova coated Sebastopol the following morning The 19th PORNOS Bome interesting relics of the Orimean War including the colour belt worn by Lieutenant Stockwell who fell at Alma whilst carrying the colours, and whose life blood left indelible stains upon it, and also

set of Roman droms which still roll proudly at the bead of the battalion on wh oth of September, when the regimental coloar is trooped to commemorate that battle Oure turning from the Crimen in 1856 the regiment had but a brief spell of peace service, being ordered out to India, to take part in the quelling of the Mutiny, remaining in India till 1872, during which period further bonours were won in the Hazarda Expedition and the operations against the warrior tribes of the Black Mountain, gaining the thanks and praise of the Viceroy of India. The second battalion w wided to the regiment in 183 In 1881 the old number was discarded and the regi ment received the designation of the Princess of WalenYorkshire Regiment Three years later, the 1st battalion was engaged in the Nile expedition, and the subsequent Soudan Campaign, under General Sir B Stephenson, being present at the action of Ginnin. Two years were spent on the banks of the Nile, and no battalion could wish for a harder time than fell to their lot in the waste of sand. In 1999 when the Boer War wm looming the 1st Battalion was recalled home from Gibraltar and rapidly mobilised for active service. It embarked for the Cape on the 24th November, numbering 958 of all raoke under the com mand of Lieutenant Colonel H. Bowlen. The mobilisation of the Green Howarda" made them a corpe second to none in appearance, the average heigbt being 5 ft. 9 inches. The battalion on arrival was despatched to the Colesberg district where General Prench w operating against the Boers, and getting their first taste of warfare at Slingerstontein, where D Co. was specially complimented by General Prench for their bravery in turning the Boers off the hills. Atter a month's hard fighting in the Colesberg distriot the battalion joined Robert's force who trapped wily Cronje in the deep ber of the Modder River at l'ardeberg The 19th formed part of the 18th Brigade and mar ched from Enslin on February 11th, and night on up to the 27th, when the Boers surrendered, it was long marching and hard fighting all the time. In the meantime the battalion had distin Roished themselves at the fight for kitchener's Kop, which resulted in the attempted relieving movement by De Wat being defeated

Sergt. now Sergt. May Pickard won the Dia tinguished Conduct Medal for his gallant lead ing of a party to turn some Boers off one of the lower crests of Kitchener Kop After the surrender of Cronje the battalion formed part of the force Lord Roberts led to Bloemfontein, and shared at the operations of Driefontein, Paardeberg cost the Green Howards 162 of all rank, but the battalion went on and won three battle honours. With the victorious British troops it entered Jobannesburg and Pretoria, and in the operatione iu the Fasteru Transvaal w present at the battles of Diamond Hill and Belfast. Long and tedious but valuable the work we afterwards done in garrisoning the blockbouses, and wben peace was proclaimed on June 1st, 1902, all were devoutly thankful During those many, many months of active wartare the battalion lost 226 killed and wound od in action, and 92 dier of disene, heavy toll of brave men who have pain shown bow British soldiers aan die and suffer in their un try'GRUS

The bonouns on the regimental colours of the Green Howards are Malplaquet, "Alma" "Inkerman," "Sevastopol," "Tirah," "Sonth Africa, 1899 1909," "Relief of Kimberley" and "Paardeberg." and they also bear the monogram of her Majesty, her coronet and the date 1875

The battalion bears a very fine reputation for efficieney and discipline and quite recently ber Majesty presented colours to it at Buckin gham Palace. Ita record a shooting battalion is an enviable one.

div.head: GENERAL AND MRS BULLOCK "AT HOME."
div.p: The ball given on Wednesday night by Major General and Mrs. Bullock wm the first large entertainment given this season at the General's bous, and ww held later than usual owing to the unfortunate illnes of Mrs. Bullock, from which she is now happily recover ed It wus in every way most brilliant and successful fonction and was attended by very nearly five bondred of the best known residents and visitors in the place. The bouse is beautifully arranged for anch entertainments, the drawing room making finely proportioned dancing ball and the ante rooms, and pas Rupes, and staircase affording plenty of sitting out room With such a crowd, dancing was con tinued under certain diffeulties, though & perfect door and excellent music tempted most people. General and Mrs. Bullock received their guests in the ante room and Mine Bullock and Min Ottway were everywhere, doing much to add to the enjoyment of the even ing. The toilettes wom were all delightful, and many of the Indies wore magnificent jewelr. The programme was a long one for Cair, where generally people have to be content with some dozen dancer but the evening power all too quickly nevertheless, in spite of many of the guests having been ap Inte the night before Indeed this dance wu one of the plenantest functions of the season, and General and Me Bullock may rest satisfied in their minds that there was not one guest who did not enjoy him or herselt. Major General Ballook is coming to Alex andria today and will stay at the Now Khedivial Hotel

Baron de Kosel Bey left yesterday by the 8.8 "Cairo" for Marseilles. The Baron is proceerling to England in order to make the De ry Arrangements in connection with his dsughters wedding which is to take place shortly in London

Lieutenant and Assistant Comminary, of Ordnance A. Sargeant, AOD, has arrived from Bngland in relief of Lieutenant and H.C.O.T. Rees Mr. Sargeant is very well known in Egypt, this being the third occasion of his connection with the Army Ordnance Department in Egypt.

Mrand Mrs. A 0 Lamplough are leaving for l'pper Egypt by to night's train de luxe They will go straight to Assouan, where they will stay at the Cataract Hotel, and where Mr. Lamplough will exbibit some of his wonderful water colour drawings,

The Tress which Mrs. Irene Harvey Irene Osgood of Guilsborough Hall, wore at Shep beard's grand annual ball was immensely admired by all present and it has occurred to us that our lady readers might like to have the technical description of name. It wa copied by a firm of Parisian dressmakers from

Plorentine portrait of a mly in Court dress of two centuries ago and was composed of gown of moiré silver cloth, out in the Princess style, with a long train Over this was hang # olinging drapery of fine Rassino white net, most exquisitely band embroidered in frostert silver threal with opal, pearls, and diamonds representing tropical foliage tendrila, vines leaves, fruit and Hwers The only incon venience of this beautiful dress was the great weight of the embroideries jewelr ete, at this added much to the fatigue of the lay's daties With her freue Mrs Harvey wore her world famous fire opals as well as some of her diamond. Her coiffure was very simple one, but not the lens effective on that secount, and she had placed only one small diamond pray in her p ofuse, reddy hair

div.head: PORTS AND LIGHTS SCANDALS
div.p: The Finance Ministry has issued a notice announcing the dismissal of Mr. Bruidas Poggio, engineer in the service of the Porta and Lights Administration, for grave irregularities committed by that official. The dismimal will take effect us from the 26th November last The Financial Ministry has sino inned . similar notice in regard to Mr. Henry Lemaire, an engineer in the same administration. This dismissal is to take effect from the 24th October last.

div.head:
HOUSE OF LORDS.
LORD CURZON'S CLAIM
THE MACEDONIAN QUESTION

div.p: House of Lords. The Lords have admitted Lord Curzon's claim. He has taken the oath and his soat. The Lord Chancellor is satisfied that bo is entitled to be elected (Reuter)
To the debate yesterday evening Lord Ripon referring to Macedonia said that the Govern tout would use every effort to maintain the concert of Europe.
Questions were involved which might give rise to a war between Great Britain and Turkey, leading inevitably to European war which would be attended with the greatest evils conceivable.
(Reuter)

Sir E. Grey has proposed to the Powers to increase the Macedonian gendarmery and to employ it in pursuit of the bands. The Porte is greatly impressed and will vigorously oppose anything consolidating or extending the powers of the Buropean officered gendarmery fearing that it would lead to the establishment of a European force. She is consequently organizing 12 flying columns to deal with the bands.
The Porte has replied to the Anglo Russian representations, promising to telegraph to ar Test any forward movement. She denied any intention to seize Sajbalak which she admits is in Persian territory
(Reiter
House of Commons. Sir H. Campbell Banner man was absent and Mr. Asquith acted as leader
Mr. Redmond gave notice of a Home Rule resolution and asked for time for discussion.
Sir C. A. Spring Rice will not resume his post at Teheran on the grounds of health
In the debate on the Address Lord Lans downe and Mr. Balfour criticized the British Concessions in Persia by the Anglo Russian agreement and dwelt on the lawless state of Irelapi.
Mr. Balfour announced an official amendment with reference to the deplorable state of Ireland.
(Reuter)
Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman was still absent. Mr. Balfour, who is suffering from influenza, and the Speaker, from gout, were also absent.
(Reuter)

At the Commission of Foreign Affairs of the Austrian Delegation, M. Gabrinski protested against the anti-Polish policy of Prussia, which, he said, reflected the German foreign policy. Austria must seek again the support of France and Germany.
(Havas)
The New Amsterdam National Bank, with liabilities amounting to 4,500,000 dollars, and the Mechanics and Traders Bank, with a capi tal of 2,000,000 dollars, have closed their doors
(Reuter)

Reichstag. The naval Bill has passed the second reading. Replying to Herr Bebel who protested that the increase in the navy was only aimed at Great Britain, Herr Tirpitz declared that Germany was strengthening the navy merely on the principle that those who are friends to day might be enemies to morrow He failed to see anywhere a cause of conflict between Great Britain and Germany. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE FUTURE OF EUROPE.
DANGERS OP DELCASSBISM

div.p: A communiqué published in Prince von Buelow's organ says that the future does not belong to Delcasséism. Europe can never be come tranquil amid a dance of "ententes" round a single power. Such a policy exercises pressure which generates counter-pressure.
(Reuter)
Rioting took place here yesterday. The police dispersed groups armed with revolvers. Several persons were injured, mostly policemen
An official note states that concerted attacks on the police took place in different quarters on Tuesday evening, during which one was killed and several wounded.
These attacks indicate an anti-government plot. Numerous arrests have been made, in cluding republican and progressist leaders.
(Reuter)
The cholers bas decreased the deaths now nnmber 100 daily.
(Reuter
The Russian press is angry at Baron Aebrenthal's speech and accuses Austria with duplicity regarding the near Eastern questions.
(Rorster)
Sutragettes to day besieged the houses of six Cabinet Ministers. Disorders and arrests resulted. 7 of them went to prison for six weeks
(Reuter
It is stated that that Sir James Rennell Rodd will succeed Sir E. E. Egerton who is retiring from the Rome Embassy. (Reuter)

div.head: ENGLISH COMPANIES IN EGYPT
div.p: AN IMPORTANT DECISION.

Yesterday afternoon the British Consular Court at Alexandria pronounced judgment on & case of the highest importance to the many companies, registered under the English Companies Acts, but whose sphere of operations is in Egypt, and whose boards are wholly or I partially composed of non-British directors. In October last an English shareholder in the Bourse and Banking Company of Egypt Limited applied to the British Consular Court at Alexandria for the removal of Mr. Alfred Nahren. the liquidator of that Company, on the grounds that he was administering the state in the interests of the directors. The liquidator pleaded that the Consular Court was incompetent to decide the case. The Court held that in as such as the applicant was a British sobject and the Company was registered under the English Companies Acts, therefore it bad jurisdiction. The liquidator then appealed to H.B.M. Supreme Consular Court for the Dominions of the Sublime Ottoman Porte and the appeal was heard in December last, Judge Cator upholding the judgment of the lower court. Yesterday the original application was renewed before the Consular Court. Mr. Reginald Silley, with whom was Mr. Gooding, appeared for the applicant and the liquidator was represented by Mr. Whitworth. Mr. Reginald Billey argued that the liquidator should be removed on the grounds that he bed shown partiality in favour of the members of the board of directors, such partiality being proved by the fact that he had refused information to the present applicant and caused difficulties to shareholders in the obtention of their share warrants, thus preventing them from exercising whatever voting power they had and 80 increasing the intinence of the Board, notably Messrs. Arditi. A second point was that, Mr. Nabman, being a non British subject, the penalties provided by the Companies Acts for failure to comply with the same by a liquidator, could not be enforcer against him personally. As an example counsel quoted section 15 of the Act of 1890, which imposed a penalty of £50 per day for noncompliance with the provisions of that section. Mr. Silley then quoted the case or the Sir John Moore Gold mining Company (reported in 12 Chancery Division, wherein a shareholder had sought for the removal of a liquidator on the grounds of his having refused information to the applicant and having expressed favourable view, with regard th the conduct of the directors of the Company. This Case went to appeal and the late Lord Justice Jessel, Master of the Rolls, confirmed the removal of the liquidator on the above grounds. Mr Silley furthermore contended that the present case was even stronger than the one cted 'This in the barenbiders 'had in that one brieted counsel to appear and op pove the removal on the ground that they were all satisfied with the liquidator. More over, quoting the words of the learned Lord Justice, Mr. Silley contended that "owing to his (the liquidator's) intimate connection with and favourable disposition towards the Directors," he was a person "onfitted in the wide and general sense of the term to hold the position of liquidator." Counsel contended that this was suthcient without shy morn impropriety on the part of the liquidator, which was not alleged in any way by the Applicant

Mr. Whitworth, for the defendant, contended that the affidavits filed were unreliable as evidence and furthermore that the only serious point was the alleged refusal of the liquidator to give information to the applicant. He quoted the case of the Adam Byton Company Limited reported in the Chancery Division), to show that the Court was bound to consider the real and substantial interests in the liquidation, and that therefore the Court should not act simply on the judgment in the case quoted by the applicant.

Counsel contended that the written application for information had been made under & wrong section of the Act and so the liquidator was not bound to answer it. Mr. Whitworth went on to say that the case had been bolstered up by unauthorised reports in the newspapers, and asked the Court to express & sting op! nion upon the case

Mr. Silley in reply pointed out that the case quoted by the other side did not affect the previous decision because it merely gave additional reasons for removing a liquidator. Counsel contended that the applicant had acted with great public spirit in bringing this question of principle before the court. A great deal had been said about the facility afforded by English law in company formation, and foreigners, who took advantage of these facilities and enjoyed the privileges of Englisb law, should be also made to feel the responsibilities of that law

The Judge, in summing up, said that he had come to the conclusion that a case had been made out for the removal of the present liquidator. If for no other reason, the difficulties of enforcing penalties against a foreign liquidator, dealing with assets of a British Company, would be a sufficient ground for removing him. In the opinion of the Court it was undesirable that the voluntary liquidations of Britieb Companies should be confided to any but British subjects. The Court therefore ordered the removal of the present liquidator, but felt some difficulty in choosing there and then a successor. Counsel for the applicant submitted that under the section of the Act the Court must itself proceed to nominate a liquidator and that, pending such nomination, be asked the Court to direct the Registrar to take possession of the books, papers, accounts and monies of the Company. Mr. Nahman agreed to hand these over and the Court accordingly gave directions.
The costs were ordered to be paid out of the funds of the Company.

Now ensued a highly interesting episode. The Marshal of the Court, accompanied by Mr. Gooding, proceeded to the offices of the Company which be found closed, with a notice on the door referring ballets to the offices of Mr. Nahman. The Marshal and Mr. Gooding straightway proceeded to Mr. Nabman's offices and demanded delivery of the books, etc. Mr. Nahitnan informed them that he was an Austriah subject and would not give up the belongings of the Company

If anything was wanting to justify the view of the Court as to the absolute necessity of removing Mr. Nahuan and the undesir ability of allowing foreigners to deal with assets of British Companies, Mr. Nahman's attitude provides a complete justification and will not, it is feared, in any way contribute to allay the suspicions of the publie us to the state of this Company's affairs.

div.head: EGYPTIAN MINING
div.p: Mr. John Wells, the late head of the now defumet Mining Department sends the following letter to "The Mining Journal":
I was interested in your issue of the 4th inst. in reading the article on the Egyptian Department of Mines from a correspondent in Alexandria
At a time when so many rumors more or less detrimental to mining interests in Egypt are being circolated, I may, perhaps, be forgiven for taking a somewhat personal interest in the subject.

Writing ex officio, the Government in July last made up their minds to reduce the establishment of the Department of Mines, expressing the opinion that circumstances warranted the strictest economy in public finance, and that the present state of the mining industry in Egypt did not call for the foll Department of Mines, which had been considered necessary to carry out the previous decision of the Government to render every possible assistance and encouragement towards the development of the mineral industry as a whole rather than to specialise in gold mines only.

The special circumstances which called for a relation came at an inopportune moment, and unless fully understood must be detrimental to the interests of mining in Egypt, coming 29 they do at the moment when the old exclusive concessions expire and the country is for the first time open to all.comers for prospecting the der general licenses, and, more especially, as the Department of Mines would have completed the preliminary examination of the mineral belts by the end of 1908.

So far as the examination of the country has been made, there is no doubt that at one period ip ber history mining in Egypt was an important industry, giving employment to many thomadatlakortet, overreger,&c.addnat when the Egyptians themselves recommence the development of the old mines success will assuredly attend their efforts in many instances, but that until local capital and efforts can be induced to take up the mineral industry no very material advance can reasonably be anticipated, except, perhaps, in a few special cakes: this much to be desired phase (conspi cuongly absent in the past) is to a very great extent in the hands of those responsible for the administration of Egypt, and their attitude towards industries other than agriculture. Much may be accomplished by a little sympathy and encouragement, coupled with some practical assistance and demonstration in the more commercial side of the industry, more especially in reference to cements, pottery, faiences, artificial manures, &c.

Under the general policy prior to the present necessity for retrenchment in public finance, local subjects had begun to take an intelligent interest in the possibilities of the mining in dustry, and at least one local syndicate is taking determined steps to open up the old mines and demonstrate their potential value with the help of a three-stamp prospect mill. Certainly it is the first local attempt; but it must not be forgotten that until the middle of 1907 such work by local subjects was impossible owing to the whole of the mineral belts being locked up in the hands of Buropean syndicates holding huge areas under exclusive licenses. Moreover, the Egyptian deserts were a sealed book to inhabitants of the towns on the Nile; and it was not until these river residents bad been taught that the desert areas of mountain and plain were by no means as difficult of access as they had been accustomed to assume that any considerable movement towards their development became possible. Even the prospectors talds of antold wealth could not break down the boundary between the Nile and the enstern regions with their unknown hardships and tertors.

Six years ago bardly a native in Egypt understood anything about mines or mining in fact, it was only by holding out consider able inducement that a labourer could be induced to proceed underground at all, and the few fellahin that could be persuaded to leave the Nile had a very real dread, not only of the hardships of the desert bat also of the danger they ran from maltreatment by its inhabitants.

To-day, this is all changed; the fellah has no fear of the desert; on the other hand, be is that in his journeyings, risking death by thirst in departhog from the beaten track, and lacking the local knowledge of the whereabouts of wote and water boles. Among the natives who have been trained on the mines are many who prove themselves capable miners, being intelligent, easily taught, and do not
require nearly as much supervision as is usually necessary with other native rade in Africa.

Local subjects and syndicates undertaking prospecting phoebe great advantages over their less fortunate Buropean competitors and in their understanding of local conditions and language are able to accomplish & mueb greater amount of work for an equal expenditure. Local subjects, however, yet lack the requisite technical knowledge of mining. Mnch of this could, however, be supplied in the first instance by the Government engineers and inspectors taking a kindly interest in their ventures, under which conditions there are many small mines which could be successfully operated by local residents and syndicates. From among them will be mines requiring more capital and skill for their final development, which, no doubt, would be readily forthcoming either from abroad or locally, assisted by expert Enropean engineers, BO BOOD as it was recognised that the onus of preliminary exploration and development was upon the shoulders of the Egyptian himself.

The public seldom trouble themselves to appreciate the local conditions and circumstances... stanoes of new field, and they certainly have never understood Egypt in regard to her mi Deral industry. To them, a "gold mine" is a "gold mine," and a new field means "gold mines," for the very good reason that the early adventurers in a field must part with a portion or the whole of their wares (usually gold). The old, old story is repeated; the old, old game played to a publiotever gullible when its palate is tickled with tales of wealth It is said that the public learn as time goes on. They do, and they do not for those who learn to day are for ever being replaced by those anxious to learn for themselves what their fathers have already learnt

Egypt possesses in her mineral belts gold, copper, lead, sulphur, phosphates, nitrates, emeralds, peridots, and many other minerals of commercial value in her old mines she basa potential wealth waiting for the investment of her surplus funds Many of these mines can be made to pay if reasonably handled and capitalised but the future of the industry lies in the hands of her own people, aided by local as well as ont side capital, and without doubt these latent resources will in due course le developed

In addition to the more hazardous side of her mineral industry, exemplified in the nines situated in the desert regions, Egypt possesses in the vicinity of the Nile considerable potential wealth in the development of the manufacture of cements, potteries, friences, chemical fertilisers, &c. Materials for these are in great abundance, and local demand more than sufti cient to warrant their development. Great strides in these latter would have been made during the next two years had the Government been able to carry on the general policy laid down for 1908 and 1909, for not only would their laboratory and pottery works (now lying idle at Edfn have determined finally the commercial value of the clays, refractory anil otherwise, but the staff of the department would have been able to devote its whole energies to the complete preliminary examination of the various mineral belts, phosphate and nitrate areas

Maps are now available for practically the whole of the eastern desert, as a basis for correlation and plotting of the data collected for the last few years, and a territory embracing some 70,000 square miles, utterly known few years ago, is now thoroughly opened up

It is more than unfortunate that the Government should have felt compelled to economie at the ebb stage of the mining industry, as, in addition to giving a set back to foreign interest, their action in taking away the support previously tendered will ge far to holding back to cal capital and create a want of confidence among many who had begun to take an intelligent interest in the development of Egypt's re sources other than agricultural, finding that they were assured of the best technical advice as the value of their samples and for guidance in their preliminary explorations.

Fuel is, perhaps the most difficult subject that local industries have to consider still, the manufacture of cement in competition with it ported cement has been found possible and there is no doubt that serious as the present lack of fuel may be, it is not absolutely an insurmountable difficulty to the manufacture of many products locally in competition with imported articles of a like nature.

It is too soon yet to despair of finding fuel in Egypt, for in addition to the oil ares aow being developed in the Gulf of Suez, the indi rations of lignite and coal have not yet been sufficiently explored to warraut any decision unfavourable to their occurrence in quantities suitable for internal requirements

The Government are still in poesession of a very considerable staff of mining engineers and geologists at a cost of between L B 6,000 and LE 7,500 per annum, which should enable them to go on quietly investigating the miner al resources of the country until suel times as circumstances again warrant & more motive policy. For the present development may be retarded, but in due course force of circumstances will probably induce local capital to embark in industries other than agricultate Yours faitbfully
JURY WELL Kilmeston, near Alresford, Hanta,

div.head: LORD CROMER'S SPEECH
div.p: It is very remarkable to note bow the news papers in England have changed in their criti. cism of Lord Cromer. Last year the Conser tive Press could not be too eulogistic as to his services in Egypt, while the Liberal and Radical newspapers were full of carping criticism. Now all this is changed owing to his Lordship's free trade policy. The "Pall Mall Gazette" for example remarks: -

His denunciation of Old Age Pensions as "demoralising," and his conjuration of the working classes that they and their families should be independent of assistance afforded to them by the general body of taxpayers," come, we cannot help saying, with a certain incongruity from one who has accepted a most substantial gift from the same taxpayers' gene rosity The principle that pensions are only for proconsuls is not one that will rally many voters, we fear, to the standard of the eminent and intelligent coterie before whom these sentiments were expressed yesterlay"

div.head: MRS SHELDON AMOS.
div.p: last week we announced the death at Cairo of Mrs Sheldon Amos. The Daily News" publishes the following sketch of her career
A very large circle of liberals, in this and other countries, as well as of private friends, will receive with grief the announcement of the death of Mrs Sheldon Amou at the age of sixty Six

Life in Cyprus

At Mr Andeath in Egypt in 1885 Met glad niet her selt tot u cation of her children and all to the energetic support in mest ngs and to mittees of the objects which she has so strong wat heart, ami wluch enhanced the entire Liberales She served on the Executive Committee of the Women - Liberal Peders tion for which she was for years instant and follow the speaker in all parts of the country and the l'on of Women Workers, and

y other bodies of a philanthropic character After the Masters in Armenia she not only helped to form a committee for affording in Cyprus refuge for the widows and orphans of the victims but herself lived for time in Cyprus t see the refuge established, and Rain visited it later when the inmates deemed the time has come when one could return to their titive land, while others went to America and Egypt. Notwithstanding all these interest And labours, Mr Amos had half her heart in Egypt, where, with ber full consent and art, her two children ultimately found their voca

Mr Maurice Amos is now a Judge of the Appeal Court at Cairo, and Miss Atos, who adopted the medical profession, holds the post of medical officer in the Mohammedan Girls High Schools at Cairo. She recently married Major Elgoord, Chief of the Government School for training the native police.
A Broad Mind
Forr some years past Mro. Amen's health bad forbidden her wintering in England, and she spent the winter in Reypt, except that last year sbe made prolonged toor round the world and in India.

An eamest, energetic, independent, and strong willed spirit, at the same time warm bearted and generous, sbe united a very broad view of things with some very firmly beld convictions Profondly and confidently religious, and sound Evangelical, she beld very loosely to any traditions or conventions either on political or ecclesiastical questions, and bad a mind ever open to new discoveries and new opinions. This babit enabled her to deal very frankly and sympathetically with people of different ways of thinking in tafe rence to their most intimate beltete sada periences. But she held firmly to the soluta supremacy of the Christian religion, and espe cially in view of her long experience in the East

She has left wide gap in the hearts ou innumerable friends, nuttew of whom bave At one time or anotber looked upon her m their counsellor and leader, and whose con solation it will be that she has lived her life strenuously and done her work nobly during
period of twenty-two years of what was a widowhood indeed after an ideal marriage, and departed in peace in the land she best lover

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Vendredi, 31 Janvier On a fait peu de chose ce matin. Il y a eu seulement quelques rares transactions sans im portance disséminées sur toute note. A gnaler pourtant l'United qui a donné lieu un assez fort courant d'arbitrages avec le Caire. Il a été question également de la Cassa di Sconto mais les transactions sur ce titre ne pa raissent pas avoir atteint beaucoup d'ampleur Quelques Agrioole ont aussi changé de mains Dans l'ensemble on avait ouvert en assez boobe tenue, c'est en cours de séance qu'on flechi, pour cloturer faible avec une tendance à la lourdeur
Avec un marché aussi restreint on conçoit que les fluctuations n'aient pas été nombreuss et qu'elles dénotent généralement une moins value
Parmi les valeurs dirigeantes, l'Agricole fie chit de 8.715 16 et la National Bank de 21 34 21 11/16, tandis que l'Obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier s'améliore de 294 296 1/2
Les Privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie se relevent de 135 & 137 et le Banco di Roma de 108 1/4 & 108 12
Au contraire, le Cheikh Fadl tombe de 90 & NS, I'Urbaine de 8 3 16 3 5 32, I'lnion Foncière de 4 516 & 1 9 32, le Credit Franco Egyptien de 4 5 32 4 3 32 La Sociéta de Pressage de 29 A 28.

Toutes les variations en petites valeurs, l'exception toutefois de la Cassa di Sconto qui progresse de 57 1 2 à 58 3.4, indiquent une moins-value : les Markets passent de 24/3 245 la Port-Said Salt de 10/6 A 10/3 et les Rita Hotels de 3/8 * 11/32.

Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de chan gements signaler. Comme on le voit parce bref exposé, la séance de ce matin n'a présente aucun intérêt, et la tendance ne laisse entre voir pour le moment aucune amélioration. C'est une preuve de plas que, malgré l'appui da dehors, notre marché est incapable d'aller de l'avant sans les affaires terme. Toute la ques tion est de savoir si le rétablissement de ce genre d'affaires n'entrainerait peu de graves conséquences

Lundi prochain, 3 février, aura lieu une im portante vente aux encheres 224 actions Entreprises Urbaines et Rorales, 515 Delta Land and Investment, 160 Cassa di Sconto, 850 Egyptian Estates, 80 Obligations anciennes Crédit Foncier Egyptien et 24 nouvelles, 90 actions Anglo-American Nile, 1 part de fondateur Crédit Poncier Egyptien, 1 Obliga tion Crédit Foncier de Pranoe, 13 Obligations Chemin de fer Ottomans, et 8 arrear dividend Coupons Egyptian Delta Light Railways.

div.head: The New Egyptian Company, Limited.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that the seventh Ordinary General Meeting of the members of the New Egyptian Company, Lámited will be held on Friday the 31st day of February, 1908, at 12.30 pm.. at the Cannon Street Hotel in the city of London to receive the Report of the Directors, to appoint auditor and to transact the ordinary business of the Company
THE TRANSFER BOOK of the Company will be closed from January 31st February 21st, both days inclusive, Dated the 30th day of January 1908
By Order of the Board

THOMAS DAY, Secretary TO ENABLE holders of SHARE WARRANTS to BEARER to vote, they must deponit their warrants at the cities of the Company, 34, Clement's Lane, London, EC on or before the 18th day of February 1908, or at the Cairo office, Haret el Daramalli, on or about the 12th day of February, 1908

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe.
Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.&O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

It is hardly necessary to point out to Tourists the extraordinary interest of a visit to Athens from an artistic, historical and archaelogical point of view, and if possible tourists should average to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara, for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS
la Municipalité met en adjudication la vente les mondices ainsi que du fumier proversnt u halayage et des beures de Ramleh
Le cantionnement est fixé A LE
le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau de Nettoiement ou il peut etre consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9h à midi, les jours ferids exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressees soos pli cacheté Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 19 Février 1908
Elles pourront également etre deposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour
sh pm
L'enveloppe levra porter en outre la men ton "Soumission pour Achat des Immondices et du fumier de Ramlah."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de La Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 février 1908 midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplie pas les conditions ci-dessus sera ecartée Alexandrie, le 29 Janvier 1908.
L'Administrateur 31849 31
(Signe) WP. CHATAWAT.
